item.title: windeln.de confirms data security incident
item.description: Munich, 16th September 2020: windeln.de SE („windeln.de“ or „Company“; ISIN DE000WNDL201) has announced today: Between June 10th and 23rd, 2020 data of some of our customers were temporarily stored on an unprotected server due to a maintenance error, which has since been corrected. The data is now safe again.

item.title: Why did I lose the ability to co_await a std::future and concurrency::task? | The Old New Thing
item.description: After upgrading to version 2.0.200729.8 of C++/WinRT, some customers reported that they lost the ability to co_await a std::future or a Concurrency::task. What happened? The relevant change is PR 702 which removed “vestigial support for free awaiters.” And that’s the part that’s relevant here.
item.author: (Raymond Chen Follow)

item.title: Integrating Thinkst Canaries with TheHive
item.description:
We've been big fans of the Thinkst [https://canary.tools] platform for a while now. We may have mentioned them a time or two :) Like many others, we get a lot of mileage out of their Canaries and Canary Tokens.
We also love TheHive [https://thehive-project.org/], as you probably already know. As we've long touted, it makes tracking incidents easy, it's reliable, and it's another well-managed open source project that we support and contribute to.
Part of our job at Recon relies on both of these
item.author: (Whitney Champion Twitter)

item.title: Security through obscurity isn't / Matiss Treinis
item.description: There has been a couple of posts (1, 2) on Reddit discussing an article Security by Obscurity is Underrated by Utku Şen. Before going any further, you should probably read the linked article. In conclusion, however, the author makes a point that - Security by obscurity is not enough by itself. You should always enforce the best practices. However, if you can reduce the risk with zero cost, you should do that.

item.title: The Great Bubble Barrier - A smart solution to plastic pollution
Reinforcement learning, non-Markov environments, and memory
item.description: I recently finished reading a reinforcement learning textbook (by Barto and Sutton), and throughout it I was constantly vexed by one important assumption that underlined all the algorithms: the Markov property, stating that a succeeding event depends only on the one preceding it, and not on ones far in the past. This kind of restriction is a helpful tool both practically and theoretically, but it causes problems when dealing with a rather natural situation where there is long-term dependence between events. The book doesn’t address this, so I tried to, and found out it’s a genuine problem with real research behind it. Here’s what I did.
item.author: (Jan Corazza)

item.title: Searching for style
item.description: It’s interesting to watch young children use home assistants. They treat them like people, asking questions like “Alexa, how are you feeling?” and “Alexa, where are you?”. I often wonder what their motivation is. Maybe they don’t know the responses are scripted. Maybe the designers’ choice of which response to script is just as interesting to them as a human’s response would be. Adults are no less inclined to anthropomorphization—Alexa is marketed as a her and not an it—but they’ve grown used to Alexa’s shortcomings as a conversationalist.
item.author: (Jacob Jackson)

item.title: Turn Your Newsletter Into an Experience — Ari Lewis
item.description: What was your favorite magazine growing up? For me, it was Game Informer , a video game magazine. I was a video game nerd who spent my childhood playing Steam and Playstation. My mom would get the mail while I'd wait in anticipation that that month's Game Informer had arrived. It was a monthly ritu

item.title: Getting the DOM to debug for you
item.description: The other day, as part of a week long effort to squash a few bugs our team had in our backlog, I came across something that promised to be a real pain in the ass.
